comments.commentBody:
Glad to see other fans thinking the same way I do. I got pounded on this blog by the Walsh/D'Antoni supporters for saying they were wrong in both their treatment of Nate Robinson, and for the direction in which they were taking the team. Now the naked emperor, Walsh has been revealed. There simply was no excuse for passing on point guards such as Brandon Jennings and Ty Lawson. Even if they considered Jennings a project... Jordan Hill over Ty Lawson?????? Look, I like Hill and I like Toney Douglas. I saw Douglas play (really for the first time) in the ACC tourney a year ago and fell in love with his game. Maybe he'll pan out... maybe Hill will too, but right not he looks an awful lot like Reynaldo Balkman all over again... except Balkman actually got on the court to vindicate Isaiah from time to time. Hill, bless his heart is a very rough diamond.

Walt (Bennett #4), I think you better make right with The Lord because I actually 'recommended' something you posted. I totally agree with you and GKR (#15)... and I pray that this move falls thru. I can't possibly see what "boost" McGrady could give the Knicks and I refuse to cheer them putting a Band-Aid where a tourniquet is needed. Even if this is a salary dump (Robert #24, you're not the only one following this courtship of McGrady) it's still a bad move because of the draft picks. McGrady will never again play for the Rockets... why are they even in position to demand anything?? Deep down inside they'll be happy to get whatever they can in return for McGrady... who (not wishing him ill) could very well turn out to be another Anfernee Hardaway or Grant Hill... once great players whose trajectories were interrupted by injuries.

Then the kicker... ESPN is reporting that a trade of Nate Robinson to the Celtics for Eddie House and some other warm body is in the works.... WHY????

God help us all in Knickerbocker land.
Billl Kolek says, "Just an unbelievable performance.  Truly a joy to watch!  He deserves all the accolades he gets."

MJL what's not adding up is your understanding of "contributory negligence"... on the part of the deceased pedestrian to be specific. I'm not trying to demean you, most laypeople have a hard time understanding the concept.. and even when they DO understand it they disagree with it.

Essentially Stallworth was convicted for the DUI because the prosecution couldn't really prove that the death was caused by Stallworth's actions alone... or whether the illegal activity of the pedestrian had a part to play as well. Acknowledging that difficulty, the Prosecution agreed to a plea bargain... even though they got Stallworth to admit to the manslaughter, they had to agree to ask for a reduced sentence in return.
Sweeeet!

Shaun White's an elite athlete of the first order and represents a sport that's available all over the world, unlike some parochial winter sports that are fun to watch (curling and biathalon, for example) but not generally enjoyed by millions of kids and adults.

He's a genuine role model for youth and obviously posesses a great work ethic in order to be able to repeat his gold medal win from four years ago.

He wears dirty blue jeans to win a gold medal and seems without pretension. How many people his age appreciate their place in the world and donate their time, reputation and energy to charitable endeavors as he has?

Tonight's second run -- when he had already secured the gold and didn't need to perform at all but nevertheless bettered his winning score - showed his skill and dedication as is seldom seen in the super stratosphere of high-powered professional athletes.

Millions of kids look up to him and for good reason -- he's raised the bar of his sport higher every year but without scandal or drugs.

If I had a child -- or a grandchild -- I couldn't think of anyone I'd rather have him emulate than Shaun White.
Hats off to this great champion in dirty jeans -- he's the real deal.

I'm with Jim on the technical achievements. Variety is the spice of life!

#18 - MoeB

I don't see how you get increased employment numbers when you have a Marxist socialist administration that routinely expresses hostility and hatred toward the very people that create jobs, invent new products, and develop profitable enterprises. The Great Depression, according to Burton Folsom, did not end until FDR had passed away and business people felt safe to pursue their capitalist objectives again.

It is true that in December 2008 the Dems said a stimulus passed quickly could hold unemployment down to 8%. However, they underestimated the scope of the Bush disaster. By inauguration, unemployment was at 7.7% and by the time the stimulus passed it was over 8%.

In the last full year of W, unemployment went from 5% to 7.7%, a 2.7% increase in real terms, and a 55% increase in the unemployment rate (2.7 / 5). In the first year of the Obama administration it went from 7.7% to 9.7%, a 2% increase in real terms, and a 27% increase in the unemployment rate 2 / 7.7) .

http://data.bls.gov...

So it's clear that we were hemmoraging jobs when Obama took office, and that has been stopped. And over 100 GOP congresspersons and senators have acknowledged this, in their own districts and states, while continuing to lie about the stimulus on a national level.
This is nothing new - conservatives always look to the past instead of the present or future. I take solace knowing they are on the losing side of history.
I make no qualms of calling republicans stupid.  Witness 2001-2009.

Evolutionary psychology is of little help to real men in the real world.

You leave out the many men who have become primary caregivers because their wives have simply walked away from their responsibilities as mothers. The social and cultural imperative for women to be "independent", "outgoing" and "fulfilled" may be more powerful for real women in America today than any archaic "mothering" impulse.

When women begin to see children as an impediment to their self-realization, they walk. And a lot of men are busy cleaning up after them. They are single fathers who work and raise their kids, and there are more and more of them every year. To be fair, these women are simply trying out a role previously reserved, if not in fact at least in the public consciousness, for men, and this is to be expected.

It is crucial, though, for young men NOT to buy into the logic of the primordial imperative, and to be aware of the possibility that one day they could wake up and find themselves transformed into single Mr. Moms, tasked with winning the bread and making the home.

Just as long as he is actually doing something useful at home.
Also, remember that a man does not bear children, and therefore, must carry even more responsibility should his wife become pregnant and has to stop working, at least for a while. When a stay at home wife is pregnant, her husband does not need to make many changes to his work schedule.
What happens should the working/provider wife goes on unpaid or extended maternity leave?Will their lifestyle still be viable?
My husband stayed home with the kids and they are pretty happy and well-adjusted.  I feel like I missed out on some fun however.

I was a stay at home dad for my 2 kids back in the mid '80s and it was the most rewarding thing I've ever done.  At the time it was a no-brainer that a man can move in and out of the work force with less penalty than a woman, so my wife steadily built a great career for herself while I was the primary care giver.  When they were old enough for school I jumped back into a new career path and after a while was back to making decent money again.  The bond I have with my kids is priceless and far exceeds anything I would have gotten out of being on a continuous career path.

I have seen this "role reversal" work and sometimes not work. Here's when it doesn't work: when the high-earning female partner grows tired of working so hard, while her hubby has time not only for the kid or kids, but for working out at the gym, hanging with his friends, making more friends, taking up more hobbies that often cost a fortune, and generally appearing to have a lot more fun in life than she can ever hope to have due to all the hours she puts in at work.

At this point, the wife puts her foot down, and one of two things happen: either the house-hubby gets a job, or, the marriage falls apart.

Again, this doesn't always happen, but I have seen it happen more than once.

"Power is in the kitchen. The big problem is not the women who stay there but the men who leave. "
David Brooks, "The Year of Domesticity," NYT 1/1/2006.

Why do I get the sense that David Brooks' sudden concern about the supposedly dismal state of the American male is part and parcel of his overall effort -- as evidenced in recent columns -- to stir up working class ("tea party") resentment of all things stereotypically liberal?
Beats me why men marry just to be live-in household drudges and babysitters.

I am the sole breadwinner and my husband takes care of our young children. I am grateful that we are able to do this because I am lucky enough to make enough to support the whole family, and he is much better at being a stay-at-home parent than I am. To all you commenters who say that men aren't as nurturing and they just will never be as good as women at taking care of the kids, I couldn't disagree with you more.  I think that there are cultural stigmas that force men (and women) to act in certain ways, but on a case by case basis, sometimes the man of a couple might be the better caregiver and sometimes the woman. In our case, my husband is more patient, more able to ham it up and have a good time with the kids and more able to deal with the routine that the children need. I love my kids more than I can explain, but when I am the primary caregiver on the weekends, I am so ready to go back to work on Monday.  And the thing is, my husband is a totally macho, handy-man, guy's guy. So, my point here is that our biology allows us a lot more flexibility than Mr. Brooks or many commenters would suggest. I think what we should be aiming for is a culture in which we support and accept that the best person for the job of primary caregiver may be a man or a woman. That doesn't mean that I think that this is the solution for the devastation that many men are experiencing in the current economy. If they would be miserable and resentful staying home with the kids, they shouldn't do it unless there aren't other options. But any man wants to be the primary caretaker of his children, has the support of his partner and thinks that he would be good at it, let's support that man in doing the most important job there is (raising the kids, that is).

How about; people do worthwhile work that they're good at, and make time for raising their kids and running the household . . . together?

And businesses recognize that people have lives outside of the workplace. And society recognizes that nurturing, empathy and the ability to support a family are the characteristics of a good parent, a well-developed adult, and lucky person. . . regardless of gender.

Encourage men to be househusbands? How do we then explain years of feminist opposition to the stay at home lifestyle? You mean it's okay to have no career of your own? That's emphatically not what feminists have been saying for the past 50 years. Feminists have insisted that the entire concept of a stay at home parent was outdated. Are we now saying they were wrong?

Gloria Steinem said: " a decent job is a basic human right for everybody"

By "everybody" did she mean only females?

The book, The Two Career Couple, asserted: "Women who hold jobs by choice, even blue-collar routine jobs, are more satisfied with their lives than are full-time housewives."

This was quoted by Ms. Steinem by means of illustrating how important it was to work outside the home. How can you now tell men that they should not work outside the home?

She also wrote, in stressing the value of working outside the home, "In addition to personal satisfaction, there is also society's need for ALL it's members' talents"

She and all feminists have stressed how working outside the home was essential for both personal fulfillment and essential for society to get the best use of all it's citizens talents. I think ALL means both men and women.

In her essay, "The Importance of Work" she wrote of the Full Employment Act of 1946: "Full employment was officially defined as 'the employment of those who want to work, without regard to whether their employment is, by some definition, necessary. This goal applies equally to men and women."

So now after years of insisting on the importance, the necessity of work outside the home, the same feminists are telling men to totally forget everything they've been telling women about how essential it is to have a career. Sorry, you spent too many years ridiculing, belittling, insulting, stay at home moms, to now do a 180 and try to convince men it's a wonderful thing.

Evolutionary psychology does rely on the idea, common throughout many species, that it is ultimately the female who has control over whose genes she's ushering into a new generation. In fact some interpretations are that patriarchy and its repressive customs are a response to this, certainly an attempt to control it. However, with the advent of the Pill (more precise control) and the dawn of an era where societies finally appreciate the contribution of half of their population, women now have even more opportunity to be selective. And they are selecting men who are more willing to be nurturing, to be involved parents and to do chores.

It's pretty obvious if you look at people under 40 all around NYC. I am not sure how that's working in the rest of the country, but I suspect that this phenomenon is irreversible. Thank god. It's better for everyone to be able to express all of their sides, be egalitarian and raise children who receive support from as many places as they can get it! Pretty soon this "phenomenon" will be as newsworthy as the idea that, gasp, we could have a Black president.
